questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Three months ago, she underwent heart transplantation for restrictive cardiomyopathy and was started on transplant rejection prophylaxis. Her pulse is 76/min and her blood pressure is 148/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows an enlargement of the gum tissue. There is a well-healed scar on her chest. Serum studies show hyperlipidemia. The physician recommends removing a drug that decreases T cell activation by inhibiting the transcription of interleukin-2 from the patient's treatment regimen and replacing it with a different medication. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of the adverse effects seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cyclosporine In addition to hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gingival hyperplasia seen in this patient, other adverse effects of this medication include hirsutism, nephrotoxicity, and neurotoxicity.

Highyeild:

Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant drug that is commonly used for transplant rejection prophylaxis. It binds cyclophilin to form a complex that inhibits calcineurin. Inhibition of calcineurin blocks activation of the NFAT transcription factors, which prevents interleukin-2 transcription and, as a result, decreases T cell activation. Cyclosporine is the only calcineurin inhibitor to cause gingival hyperplasia, so it is most likely the drug that was used in this patient.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Tacrolimus is an immunosuppressant drug. It binds FK binding protein (FKBP) to form a complex that inhibits calcineurin. Inhibition of calcineurin blocks activation of the NFAT transcription factors, which prevents interleukin-2 transcription and, as a result, decreases T cell activation. Side effects of this drug include hypertension and hyperlipidemia, as seen in this patient. However, it is not known to cause gingival hyperplasia. Option: B. Sirolimus is an immunosuppressant drug. Option: D. Glucocorticoids such as prednisolone. They exert their immunosuppressant effect via various mechanisms of action, including inhibition of NF-κB, suppression of T cell proliferation, and induction of apoptosis in lymphocytes. Glucocorticoids have a wide range of side effects including hypertension and hyperlipidemia, as seen in this patient. However, this group of drugs is not known to cause gingival hyperplasia.

Table:

Negative Effects of Cyclosporine Because Cyclosporine Is An Immunosuppressant, It May Cause Patients To Be Vulnerable To OTHER Health Problems. IT IS VERY TOXIC!!! Usage Of Cyclosporine May Cause High BP, Kidney Problems. It Also Encourages Cancerous Tumor Growth Side Effects: Headache, Vomiting, Nausea, Diarrhea, Upset Stomach, Cramps, Increased Hair Growth, Tremor, Swollen/Red/Painful Gums. Dizziness. Serious Side D : Dark Urine, Persistent Nausea/Vomiting, Severe Stomach/Abdominal Pain, Yellowing Of The Skin/Eyes, Vomit That Looks Like Coffee Grounds, Change In The Appearance Or Size Of Skin Moles/Lesions, Changes In Skin Color, Loss Of Consciousness, Mental/Mood Changes, Vision Changes, Swollen Glands, Unusual Lumps, Night Sweats

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician because she is seeing things that she knows are not there. Sometimes she sees a dog in her kitchen and at other times she sees a stranger in her garden, both of which no one else can see. She also reports a lack of motivation to do daily tasks for the past week. Three years ago, she was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease and was started on levodopa and carbidopa. Her younger brother has schizophrenia. The patient also takes levothyroxine for hypothyroidism. She used to drink a bottle of wine every day, but she stopped drinking alcohol 2 months ago. Neurologic examination shows a mild resting tremor of the hands and bradykinesia. Her thought process is organized and logical. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adverse effects of Medication While hallucinations may be caused by dysregulation of a variety of neurotransmitters, this patient's symptoms are most likely due to the activation of dopamine D2-receptors.

Highyeild:

Levodopa (L-DOPA), a dopamine precursor, is the most effective medication for controlling the motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease. Its primary effect is achieved by stimulating D2-receptors in the substantia nigra and striatum. However, overstimulation of D2-receptors by levodopa may also induce psychosis and hallucinations (usually visual). The risk of developing psychiatric symptoms increases with age, other psychiatric conditions, long duration of levodopa treatment, and high doses. Since this patient has been taking levodopa for 3 years and is elderly, her symptoms are most likely the result of levodopa therapy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. The clinical features of schizophrenia can be categorized according to the positive symptoms of psychosis and the negative symptoms of psychosis. Though this patient has an increased risk (∼ 12%) of developing schizophrenia because her brother is affected, she lacks other expected symptoms (e.g., disorganized thought process, alogia). Moreover, symptom onset at the patient's age would also be very unusual since it typically is diagnosed in the late 20s in women. Option: C. Major depressive disorder can sometimes be associated with psychotic symptoms. In addition to the features of MDD (SIGECAPS), patients may present with delusions and hallucinations, which are often auditory but can also be visual or tactile. Though this patient has hallucinations and recently noted a lack of motivation, she does not meet the criteria for a diagnosis of MDD. Option: D. Poorly controlled hypothyroidism may lead to typical complaints of fatigue, cold intolerance, and weight gain. Especially in elderly patients, hypothyroidism may also present with features similar to dementia, including impaired memory and concentration. Though hallucinations may occur, they are rare and usually accompanied by psychotic symptoms, such as paranoia and thought disorders. This patient lacks any expected signs or symptoms of hypothyroidism and has isolated hallucinations, making thyroid dysfunction unlikely.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing weakness in his arms and legs over the past year. He has also had difficulty speaking for the past 5 months. He underwent a partial gastrectomy for gastric cancer 10 years ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), his pulse is 88/min, and his blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. Examination shows dysarthria. There is mild atrophy and twitching of the tongue. Muscle strength is decreased in all extremities. Muscle tone is decreased in the right lower extremity and increased in the other extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the right lower extremity and 4+ in the other extremities. The plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left. The sensation is intact in all extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Riluzole This man has clinical features of upper motor neuron disease (increased muscle tone, extensor plantar response, and increased DTRs) as well as lower motor neuron disease (decreased muscle tone, atrophy, fasciculations, and absent DTRs), which suggest amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

Highyeild:

Riluzole REAL-lu-zole Drug used to treat amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. MOA: Glutamate blocker Inhibits voltage-dependent Na+ presynaptic neuron → decrease release of glutamate. Increase reuptake of glutamate in astrocytes.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Corticosteroids are used to treat acute exacerbations of demyelinating disorders such as multiple sclerosis. Patients with MS usually present with isolated upper motor neuron weakness, in contrast to the mixed upper and lower weakness seen here, and the clinical course of multiple sclerosis is typically characterized by periodic exacerbations and remissions. Option: C. Given the history of partial gastrectomy, this patient is at risk of developing vitamin B12 deficiency, which may present with neurological deficits such as peripheral neuropathy or subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord. Peripheral neuropathy from vitamin B12 deficiency would result in paresthesias, and/or sensory loss, while subacute combined degeneration results in a combination of progressive upper motor neuron weakness in the lower limbs and symmetrical loss of vibration and proprioceptive sensations. Decreased muscle tone, muscle atrophy, fasciculations, and asymmetrically absent DTRs would not be an expected finding. Option: D. Nusinersen was approved by the FDA in 2016 to treat spinal muscular atrophy. Patients with spinal muscular atrophy may present with progressive weakness, hypotonia, and fasciculations of the tongue, without any sensory deficits. However, the onset of symptoms typically occurs during infancy and childhood, and patients present only with features of lower motor neuron lesions, in contrast to the mixed upper and lower motor neuron weakness seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 49-year-old hypertensive male has been diagnosed with wide-angle glaucoma when he went for a routine ophthalmological examination. The following drugs can be given as topical eye drops to this patient except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Iloprost Iloprost, a PGI2 analogue produces vasodilatation & is used in the treatment of Pulmonary hypertension. Iloprost has predominant action on the pulmonary artery causing pulmonary vasodilatation and thus is helpful in pulmonary hypertension. It has no effect on uveoscleral outflow. Hence, it is not used in glaucoma.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Latanopros t, Option C. Travoprost & Option D. Bimatoprost are PGF2α analogues that are FP receptor agonists. They are the first-choice drugs in wide-angle glaucoma. They are used topically & they will increase the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humour. Option: C.Travoprost : eye drops helps to reduce eye pressure in people with ocular hypertension, and to prevent further eye damage in people with open-angle glaucoma. Travoprost eye drops work by increasing the drainage of fluid from inside your eye. Option: D. Bimatoprost is a prostaglandin analogue. It works by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor, thereby lowering the increased eye pressure. Bimatoprost helps lower high pressure in the eye and reduces the risk of vision loss. For best results, put one drop once a day in the evening/night in the affected eye (s)

questions.text: A 63-year-old male came to the casualty with symptoms of shortness of breath, dizziness & tightness in the chest. The doctor diagnosed him with pulmonary hypertension. The following drugs can be given to this patient except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alprostadil Alprostadil: (PGE1 analogue) is used in the treatment of erectile dysfunction. It is injected into the penis which causes an erection lasting 1–2 hours. However, oral sildenafil/ tadalafil is now preferred. It is also used to maintain patency of ductus arteriosus in neonates with congenital heart defects, till corrective surgery is undertaken. Apnoea occurs in a few cases. It is not used in the treatment of pulmonary hypertension.

Highyeild:

The most common side effects of Alprostadil (Alpostin Injections) are penile pain, erection lasting 4 to 6 hours (prolonged erection), penile fibrosis (deformed penis shape), bruising at the injection site, penile numbness, irritation, sensitivity, itching, swelling and discoloration, skin tears of the penis and penile rash.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Prostacyclin (also called prostaglandin I2 or PGI2) is a prostaglandin member of the eicosanoid family of lipid molecules. It inhibits platelet activation and is also an effective vasodilator. When used as a drug, it is also known as epoprostenol. The terms are sometimes used interchangeably. Option: C. Iloprost is a medication used to treat pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), scleroderma, Raynaud's phenomenon and other diseases in which the blood vessels are constricted and blood cannot flow to the tissues. This damages the tissues and causes high blood pressure. Option: D. Treprostinil, Orenitram for oral inhalation, is a vasodilator that is used for the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension. Treprostinil is a synthetic analogue of prostacyclin (PGI2).

Table:

Intraurethral Therapy Alprostadil, PGE1 (Prostaglandin E1) Via intracavernous or intra-urethral routes Urethral route (MUSE) Stimulates adenyl cyclase, which raises cAMP that leads to lower Ca++ and relaxation of smooth muscle Penile pain is a major side effect with incidence of 10-30% Hypotension and syncope with MUSE - 1 administration in the office.

questions.text: A 20-year-old primipara woman was admitted to the obstetrical unit for labour induction because of a postdated Pregnancy. Her obstetrical examination was normal, but her Cervix was unfavourable for induction of labour with oxytocin. Which of the following drugs given intravaginally would be appropriately administered at this time?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dinoprostone Prostaglandins E and F are able to terminate a pregnancy at any stage by promoting uterine contractions. They are also able to ripen the cervix (i.e., to make it softer) by increasing Proteoglycan content and changing the biophysical properties of collagen. Dinoprostone, a synthetic prostaglandin E2, is administered intravaginally for ripening of the cervix in pregnant women at or near term whose cervix is not yet soft enough for oxytocin Induction of labour.

Highyeild:

Dinoprostone (prostin E2) Vaginal pessary/gel Clinical use: IOL - 3mg 6hrs apart (no more than 2 pessaries in 24hrs and max. 3 doses) Side effect: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, fever, Uterine hyperstimulation, HTN, bronchospasm Advantages: - Mobile patient -Reduce need for syntocinon

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Thromboxanes are not used as drugs. Option: C. Ergonovine can cause uterine contractions but has no Cervical ripening properties. Option: D. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory Drugs have uterine relaxant properties, and they are devoid of Cervical ripening properties.

Table:

Drug Preparation Use Dinoprostone Vaginal tab/gel Induction labour Mid term abortion Dinoprost Intra amniotic inj Mid term abortion Carboprost IM, Intra amniotic inj Mid term abortion Control of PPH Gemeprost Vaginal pessary Cervical priming in early pregnancy Alprostadil IV infusion, IV inj Intra cavernosal inj Maintenance of a patent ductus arteriosus in neonates Erectile dysfunction Misoprostol Enoprostil Oral Abortion & Peptic ulcer Peptic ulcer Epoprostenol IV infusion Pulmonary hypertension Latanoprostol Topical Glaucoma iloprost IM Dec. infact size, when given IM after MI

questions.text: A 5-day-old premature male baby, born by normal vaginal Delivery, presented with severe cyanosis. Chest x-rays and Echocardiography confirmed the diagnosis of congenital transposition of the great arteries, and the baby was scheduled for surgery. Which of the following drugs was most likely administered by intravenous infusion to the baby until Surgery?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alprostadil When a baby is born with a congenital heart disease (transposition of the great arteries, pulmonary artery stenosis, etc.), it is important to maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus before corrective surgery. The patency of the fetal Ductus arteriosu s depends primarily on prostaglandin E2 and to a lesser extent on prostaglandin E1 . At birth, prostaglandin E1 and E2 levels are reduced because the increased Blood oxygen speeds up prostaglandin metabolism, so the Ductus arteriosus closes in 1 or 2 days. Alprostadil i s a synthetic prostaglandin E1 that can maintain the patency of the Ductus arteriosus when given after birth. Because it is metabolized quickly (the half-life is about 10 minutes), it must be given by continuous infusion.

Highyeild:

The most common side effects of Alprostadil (Alpostin Injections) are penile pain, erection lasting 4 to 6 hours (prolonged erection), penile fibrosis (deformed penis shape), bruising at the injection site, penile numbness, irritation, sensitivity, itching, swelling and discoloration, skin tears of the penis and penile rash.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Cyclooxygenase inhibitors such as indomethacin inhibit the synthesis of prostaglandin E2 and therefore are used to Speed up the closure of the ductus arteriosu s in case of delayed closure, which is common in premature infants. Option: C and D. Dinoprostone , a synthetic prostaglandin E2, and misoprosto l, a prostaglandin E1 analogue. PG E1 – Misoprostol – use for MTP PG E2 – Carboprost – useful for cervical ripening

Table:

Intraurethral Therapy Alprostadil, PGE1 (Prostaglandin E1) Via intracavernous or intra-urethral routes Urethral route (MUSE) Stimulates adenyl cyclase, which raises cAMP that leads to lower Ca++ and relaxation of smooth muscle Penile pain is a major side effect with incidence of 10-30% Hypotension and syncope with MUSE - 1 administration in the office.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman recently diagnosed with osteoarthritis started treatment with ibuprofen and misoprostol. Which of the following adverse effects is most likely expected from Misoprostol treatment?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diarrhea Misoprostol is a prostaglandin E1 analogue approved for the Prevention of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug-induced peptic ulcers. Diarrhoea is the most common adverse effect of the drug (up to 30% of patients) and is the main reason for its infrequent clinical use.

Highyeild:

Uses of misoprostol Obstetric uses: Termination of pregnancy 1st trimester 2nd trimester 3rd trimester Postpartum hemorrhage Prevention Treatment Gynecological uses Pre-hysteroscopy Intauterine Insemination (IUI) Cervical pregnancy GIT Prevention & treatment of peptic ulcer induced by NSAIDs

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Misoprostol is approved for the treatment of NSAID-induced Peptic ulcer. Option: B and C. are not expected from misoprostol treatment.

Extraedge:

Dosage of Misoprostol Take 4 tablets of misoprostol(200mg) and kept under your tongue for half an hour. After interval of 3 hours repeat the same dose of 4 tablets. Do not take 2 dosage at once.

Table:

Side effects of misoprostol Bleeding - typically lasts up to 2 weeks with spotting till next period Cramping - usually starts within the first few hours. NSAIDs can be used Fevers and/or chills - common side effect. If lasts >24 hours, evaluate for infection Nausea and vomiting - more common after oral misoprostol. Should resolve in 6 hours Diarrhea - also more common after oral miso and should resolve in 24 hours.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman came to medicine OPD because of progressive exertional dyspnea and arthralgias. Further examination led to the diagnosis of primary pulmonary hypertension, and an intravenous infusion of epoprostenol was started. Which of the following molecular actions most likely mediated the therapeutic efficacy of the drug in the patient’s disease?
questions.correct_answer: D. Activation of prostaglandin I2 receptors
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Activation of prostaglandin I2 receptors Epoprostenol is a synthetic prostacyclin (prostaglandin I2) that has powerful vasodilating activity. The drug has been approved for the treatment of primary pulmonary hypertension, a disease of unknown cause involving obliteration of medium and small pulmonary arteries and resulting in right ventricular failure or fatal syncope 2 to 5 years after detection.

Highyeild:

Epoprostenol activates specific prostaglandin I2 receptors , causing the relaxation of pulmonary arteries. Long-term therapy with this drug has been found to be highly effective in improving symptoms and prolonging survival .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options: A, B, and C . are not mechanisms of action of epoprostenol , hence all the remaining options are incorrect.

Table:

GIT: PGE 2 ↑Mucous production PGE2, PGI 2 ↑Mucosal blood flow ↓Acid secretion PGE₂↑ water and electrolytic secretion (Diarrhoea) Kidney: produced by renal medulla PGE 2 , PGI 2 Natriuresis Renal vasodilatation Inhibit ADH action Stimulate renin release PGE 2 ↓Cl- reabsorption TAX 2 Vasoconstriction ADH like action
